words.def: One of the hole cards is an ace[1]
words.name: ace in the hole

words.def: Methods of evaluating low hands. See lowball.
words.name: ace-to-five, ace-to-six

words.def: To make a play (check, bet, call, raise, or fold) at the required time, compare to in turn.
words.name: act

words.def: A player in poker that either announces their actions or physically plays before their turn ( checks, folds etc ). Sometimes players act out of turn intentionally to get a read out of other players. When done intentionally, this is often referred to as "angle shooting." See angle shooting.[1]
words.name: acting out of turn

words.def: A player's turn to act
words.name: action

words.def: A marker similar to a kill button, on which a player places an extra forced bet. In a seven-card stud high-low game, the action button is awarded to the winner of a scoop pot above a certain size, signifying that in the next pot, that player will be required to post an amount representing a completion of the bring-in to a full bet.
words.name: action button

words.def: In Texas hold 'em, and other community card poker games, a card appearing on the board that causes significant betting action because it helps two or more players.
words.name: action card

words.def: In many cardrooms, with respect to an all-in bet, only a full (or half) bet can be reraised. Anything less than a full (or half) bet is considered to be action only, that is, other players can call the bet but not raise it. Compare with full bet rule and half bet rule.
words.name: action only

words.def: A player still involved in the pot. If there are side pots, an all-in player may be active in some pots, but not in others.
words.name: active player

words.def: In a live game, to buy more chips before busting. In tournament play, a single rebuy for which all players are eligible regardless of their stack size. This is usually allowed only once, at the end of the rebuy period. The add-on often offers more chips per dollar invested than the buyin and rebuys. Compare with rebuy.
words.name: add-on

words.def: To make an obvious play or expose cards in such a way as to deliberately convey an impression to opponents about the advertising player's style of play.
words.name: advertising

words.def: The tendency for a player to open betting or raise rather than call or check. See main article: aggression. Compare with loose, tight, passive.
words.name: aggressive, aggression

words.def: A measure of a player's aggression, either in a particular betting round or over all betting rounds
words.name: aggression factor (AF)

words.def: In lowball, giving air is when a player lets an opponent who might otherwise fold know that they intend to draw one or more cards, to induce them to call.
words.name: air

words.def: When a player bets all of their chips in the current hand. See main article: all in.
words.name: all in

words.def: A permitted, but borderline unethical, play
words.name: angle

words.def: A player acting out of turn to get a read on their opponents. See acting out of turn.
words.name: angle shooting

words.def: A forced bet required, in some types of poker, of all players before the hand begins. See main article: ante.
words.name: ante

words.def: In tournament play, to force an absent player to continue paying antes, blinds, bring-ins, and other forced bets so that the contest remains fair to the other players. Also blind off.
words.name: ante off

words.def: An expression used in Texas hold 'em to say that a player's cards do not matter in a decision
words.name: any two cards

words.def: A draw requiring two or more rounds to fill
words.name: backdoor

words.def: To enter a pot by checking and then calling someone else's open on the first betting round. Usually used in games like jackpots, meaning to enter without openers.
words.name: back in

words.def: To win a pot with a hand that would have folded to any bet
words.name: back into

words.def: A reraise from a player that previously called in the same betting round
words.name: backraise

words.def: To lose a hand where one hand is considerably ahead of the eventual winning hand. See main article: bad beat.
words.name: bad beat

words.def: Playing very different hands in the same way, with the aim of making it more difficult for an opponent to gain useful information about the cards a player has.
words.name: balance

words.def: Also called the house, the person responsible for distributing chips, keeping track of the buy-ins, and paying winners at the end of the game.
words.name: bank

words.def: The amount of money that a player has to wager for the duration of his or her poker career
words.name: bankroll

words.def: Choosing the correct stakes and game type to avoid exhausting a bankroll during downswings
words.name: bankroll management

words.def: Not (currently) having the best hand
words.name: behind

words.def: Any money wagered during the play of a hand
words.name: bet

words.def: The complete set of rules regarding forced bets, limits, raise caps, and such for a particular game. See main article: betting.
words.name: betting structure

words.def: The larger of two bet amounts in a fixed limit game. See main article: big bet.
words.name: big bet

words.def: A game played with no limit or a pot limit betting structure
words.name: big bet game

words.def: The larger of two forced bets in certain types of poker. See main article: blind.
words.name: big blind

words.def: A hand won by the big blind playing very weak pocket cards because there was no raise pre-flop
words.name: big blind special

words.def: The best possible full house in community card games. A stronger hand than the underfull.
words.name: big full

words.def: A stack of chips that is relatively large for the stakes being played. Also called deep stack. Also the biggest stack at the table. Compare with short stack.
words.name: big stack

words.def: A card, frequently a community card, of no apparent value. Compare with rag, brick, bomb.
words.name: blank

words.def: A non-standard poker hand of five face cards that outranks a flush
words.name: blaze

words.def: To consistently lose chips through bad play, possibly resulting from tilting
words.name: bleed

words.def: A type of forced bet. See main article: blind.
words.name: blind

words.def: To call or raise an opponent's raise when in the big blind, rather than folding an otherwise weak hand, in order to exploit overly aggressive players.[2]
words.name: blind defense

words.def: A raise from a late position with a weak hand when all other players have folded, with the intention of winning the blinds and antes.[2]
words.name: blind steal

words.def: A stud poker game in which all cards are dealt face down. Was popular in California before legal rulings made traditional stud legal there.
words.name: blind stud

words.def: To ante off
words.name: blind off, blinded

words.def: In community card poker, holding one of the opponent's outs, typically when the board threatens a straight or straight draw. A blocker is also having a combination of cards that turn your opponent's outs into your own. Compare with dry ace.
words.name: blocker

words.def: An abnormally small bet made by a player out of position intended to discourage a larger bet by an opponent
words.name: blocking bet

words.def: A bet made with a hand that is mathematically unlikely to be the best hand, either to make money or to disguise play patterns. See main article: bluff.
words.name: bluff

words.def: The number of hands that do not have any real value left on the river, but might still be good enough to catch the bluff of an opponent[2]
words.name: bluff catching range

words.def: To make an aggressive move with a strong hand to give the impression it is a bluff, in order to draw a bluff from an opponent
words.name: bluff induce

words.def: The set of community cards in a community card game
words.name: board

words.def: Another name for a full house
words.name: boat

words.def: Both halves of a split pot, often declared by a player who thinks he or she will win both low and high
words.name: both ways

words.def: Trick or cheating deal where a card or cards are dealt from the bottom of the deck rather than the top. See main article: bottom dealing.
words.name: bottom dealing

words.def: The lowest of several possible straights, especially in a community card game. Also idiot end.
words.name: bottom end

words.def: In a community card game, a pair (or set) made by matching the lowest-ranking board card with one (or two) in one's private hand. Compare second pair, top pair.
words.name: bottom pair, bottom set

words.def: An aspect of some poker tournaments that rewards players for eliminating other players with a cash prize for each player they eliminate, separate from the tournament payout structure. See main article: bounty.
words.name: bounty

words.def: The chip tray in front of a house dealer, and by extension, the house dealer's position at the table
words.name: box

words.def: A card encountered face-up in the assembled deck during the deal, as opposed to one overturned in the act of dealing. Most house rules treat a boxed card as if it does not exist; that is, it is placed aside and not used. Different rules cover cards exposed during the deal.
words.name: boxed card

words.def: In a draw poker game, to discard cards that make a made hand in the hope of making a better one. In a jacks-or-better draw game, a player breaking a high pair must keep the discarded card aside, to prove they had openers.
words.name: break

words.def: A blank, though more often used in the derogatory sense of a card that is undesirable rather than merely inconsequential,. Also known as a bomb. Compare with rags.
words.name: brick

words.def: A brick and mortar casino is a real casino based in a building, as opposed to an online casino. This refers to many real world locations as opposed to their Internet counterparts.
words.name: brick and mortar

words.def: Poker is neutral about suits, but in determining the dealer at the start of a game, or in determining the bringin bettor in a stud game, bridge rank rules are used: spades beat hearts beat diamonds beat clubs.
words.name: bridge order

words.def: To open a betting round
words.name: bring in

words.def: A 10 through ace straight. Can also include any group of cards from 10 to ace.
words.name: broadway

words.def: A casino employee whose job it is to greet players entering the poker room, maintain the list of persons waiting to play, announce open seats, and various other duties (including brushing off tables to prepare them for new games, hence the name).
words.name: brush

words.def: The last finishing position in a poker tournament before entering the payout structure
words.name: bubble

words.def: The factor by which the odds in chips differ from the odds in dollars.[2] See also main article: expected value.
words.name: bubble factor

words.def: Marker to indicate which player is dealer (or last to act). See button.
words.name: buck

words.def: A limited wild card. See main article: bug. Compare with wild card.
words.name: bug

words.def: A player who raises frequently to force out more cautious players, especially one with a large stack for the size of the game[3]
words.name: bully

words.def: A card that is removed from the deal to prevent cheating. See main article: burn card.
words.name: burn card, burn

words.def: An uncompleted hand
words.name: busted

words.def: Most commonly a marker that indicates the dealer position at the table, but other specialized buttons exist. See main article: button. Also buck or hat.
words.name: button

words.def: The minimum required amount of chips that must be bought to become involved in a game or tournament
words.name: buy-in

words.def: To buy into a game for an amount smaller than the normal buy-in
words.name: buy short

words.def: A rule originating in northern California casinos in games played with blinds, in which a new player sitting down with the button to their right (who would normally be required to sit out a hand as the button passed, then post to come in) may choose to pay the amount of both blinds for this one hand (the amount of the large blind playing as a live blind, and the amount of the small blind as dead money), play this hand, and then receive the button on the next hand as if they had been playing all along. See public cardroom rules.
words.name: buy the button

words.def: Making a bet when no one else is betting so as to force the other players to fold, thus winning the pot uncontested. A specialized version of this is buying the blinds by making a large raise in the first round forcing all other players out of the hand.
words.name: buy the pot

words.def: To match a bet or raise. See main article: call.
words.name: call

words.def: A method of discouraging players from taking an excessively long time to act. When someone calls the clock, the player has a set amount of time in which to make up their mind; if they fail to do so, their hand is immediately declared dead. In tournament play, any player can call a clock.
words.name: call the clock

words.def: A player who frequently calls bets, but rarely raises them. A calling station is usually a loose passive player. See main article: calling station.
words.name: calling station

words.def: A limit on the number of raises allowed in a betting round. Typically three or four (in addition to the opening bet). In most casinos, the cap is removed if there are only two players remaining either at the beginning of the betting round, or at the time that what would have otherwise been the last raise is made.
words.name: cap

words.def: Similar to cap above, but refers to a no-limit or pot limit game with a cap on the amount that a player can bet during the course of a hand. Once the cap is reached, all players remaining in the hand are considered all-in.
words.name: cap game

words.def: See main article: cards speak
words.name: cards speak

words.def: The last available card of a certain description
words.name: case card

words.def: A game where each hand is played for real money as opposed to tournament play. See main article: ring game.
words.name: cash game

words.def: An announcement, usually by a dealer, that a player who has requested to buy chips and can bet the cash they have on the table in lieu of chips until receiving their chips. In many card rooms, it also refers to the policy that $100 bills may remain on the table and are considered to be in play in cash form, rather than converted to chips.
words.name: cash plays

words.def: Winning a share of the prize money in a tournament
words.name: cashing

words.def: Exchanging chips for cash when leaving a game. Removing money from an online poker site.
words.name: cashing out

words.def: To receive needed cards on a draw. Often used with an adjective to further specify, catch perfect, catch inside, catch smooth.
words.name: catch

words.def: To successfully complete a draw, thus defeating a player who previously had a better hand
words.name: catch up

words.def: To catch the only two possible cards that will complete a hand and win the pot, often those leading to a straight flush. Usually used in Texas hold 'em. Compare with runner-runner.
words.name: catch perfect

words.def: The main pot in a table stakes game where one or more players are all in
words.name: center pot

words.def: To call a bet to see the next card when holding a drawing hand when the pot odds do not merit it
words.name: chase

words.def: To bet nothing. See main article: check.
words.name: check

words.def: To fold, in turn, even though there is no bet facing the player. In some games this is considered a breach of the rules equivalent to folding out of turn.
words.name: check out

words.def: Deceptive play whereby a player initially checks with the intention of raising should another player bet. See main article: check-raise.
words.name: check-raise

words.def: A small disk or tablet used in place of money. See casino token.
words.name: chip

words.def: A method of declaring intent to play high or low in a split-pot game with declaration. See declaration.
words.name: chip declare

words.def: A strategy whereby one player deliberately loses chips to another player. Where players have agreed to take such action together, this is a form of collusion.
words.name: chip dumping

words.def: The player currently holding the most chips in a tournament (or occasionally a live no limit game)
words.name: chip leader

words.def: An event in tournament poker where chips of a value lower than the minimum required are removed from play. See main article: chip race.
words.name: chip race

words.def: To exchange lower-denomination chips for higher-denomination chips. In tournament play, the term means to remove all the small chips from play by rounding up any odd small chips to the nearest large denomination, rather than using a chip race.
words.name: chip up

words.def: To split a pot because of a tie, split-pot game, or player agreement
words.name: chop

words.def: Ending a hand when all players have folded to the blinds with the blinds being returned to those who paid them. See main article: chopping the blinds.
words.name: chopping the blinds

words.def: Making the minimum raise. Refers to online poker where players click the raise button without specifying the amount of raise.
words.name: click raise

words.def: See main article: closed
words.name: closed

words.def: Talking in an attempt to mislead other players about the strength of a hand. This is also called speech play.
words.name: coffee housing

words.def: A situation where two players have invested all their money in the pot and have a roughly even chance of winning. Also race.
words.name: coin flip

words.def: To call an amount that represents a sum of bets or raises by more than one player. Compare with flat call, overcall.
words.name: cold call

words.def: A "stacked" deck (a deck arranged in a preset order, to effect a specific outcome once dealt) which is deceptively switched with the original deck of cards in play, to the benefit of the player/dealer making the switch.
words.name: cold deck

words.def: A form of cheating involving cooperation among two or more players. See cheating in poker.
words.name: collusion

words.def: To exchange small-denomination chips for larger ones
words.name: color change, color up

words.def: A casino table at which multiple forms of poker are played in rotation
words.name: combo, combination game

words.def: A bet or raise made with a drawing hand, building the pot in anticipation of filling the draw
words.name: come bet, on the come

words.def: See main article: community card poker
words.name: community card

words.def: See made hand
words.name: complete hand

words.def: To raise a small bet up to the amount of what would be a normal-sized bet. See table stakes.
words.name: completion

words.def: Two or more cards of consecutive or close to consecutive rank
words.name: connectors

words.def: A bet made after the flop by the player who took the lead in betting before the flop (Texas hold 'em and Omaha hold 'em). Also called a c-bet. Compare with probe bet.
words.name: continuation bet

words.def: A situation in which a player holds the second best hand, so strong considering the circumstances, that they are apt to lose the maximum with it no matter how they play it
words.name: cooler

words.def: The act of counting the cards that remain in the stub after all cards have been dealt, done by a dealer to ensure that a complete deck is being used
words.name: countdown

words.def: See main article: counterfeit. Also duplicate.
words.name: counterfeit

words.def: A player with whom one is sharing a buy-in, with the intent to split the result after play. To go cow is to make such an arrangement.
words.name: cow

words.def: In some community card games, to cripple the deck means to have a hand that is virtually impossible for anyone else to catch up to.
words.name: cripple

words.def: Calling when a player thinks they do not have the best hand
words.name: crying call

words.def: See main article: cut
words.name: cut

words.def: A distinctive card, usually stiff solid-colored plastic, held against the bottom of the deck during the deal to prevent observation of the bottom card
words.name: cut card

words.def: The seat immediately to the right of the dealer button. In home games where the player on the button actually shuffles and deals the cards, the player in the cutoff seat cuts the deck (hence the name).
words.name: cutoff

words.def: An action taken before receiving information to which the player would normally be entitled. Compare with blind.
words.name: dark

words.def: A blind that is not live, in that the player posting it does not have the option to raise if other players just call. Usually involves a small blind posted by a player entering, or returning to, a game (in a position other than the big blind) that is posted in addition to a live blind equal to the big blind.
words.name: dead blind

words.def: See dead button rule
words.name: dead button

words.def: A player's hand that is not entitled to participate in the deal for some reason, such as having been fouled by touching another player's cards, being found to contain the wrong number of cards, being dealt to a player who did not make the appropriate forced bets, etc.
words.name: dead hand

words.def: See main article: dead man's hand
words.name: dead man's hand

words.def: See main article: dead money
words.name: dead money

words.def: To distribute cards to players in accordance with the rules of the game being played
words.name: deal

words.def: In a cash game, when two players are involved in a large pot and one is all-in, they might agree to deal the remaining cards twice. If one player wins both times they win the whole pot, but if both players win one hand they split the pot. Also, play twice, run it twice.
words.name: deal twice

words.def: The person dealing the cards
words.name: dealer

words.def: A version of poker in which the deal passes each game and each dealer can choose, or invent, a new poker game each hand or orbit. See main article: dealer's choice.
words.name: dealer's choice

words.def: To verbally indicate an action or intention. See declaration.
words.name: declare

words.def: A stack of chips that is relatively large for the stakes being played. Also called a big stack. Compare with short stack.
words.name: deep stack

words.def: Making a play that defends the player against a bluff by forcing the suspected bluffer to fold or invest further
words.name: defense

words.def: A two-spot card. Also called a duck, quack, or swan.
words.name: deuce

words.def: A method of evaluating low hands. See main article: deuce-to-seven low.
words.name: deuce-to-seven

words.def: A stack of chips apparently of a single denomination, but with one or more chips of another. Usually the result of inattention while stacking a pot, but may also be an intentional deception.
words.name: dirty stack

words.def: To take a previously dealt card out of play. The set of all discards for a deal is called the muck or the deadwood.
words.name: discard

words.def: A hand that is extremely unlikely to win against another specific hand, even though it may not be a poor hand in its own right. Most commonly used in Texas hold 'em. See also domination.
words.name: dominated hand

words.def: A bet made by a donk, or one that is generally considered weak or to demonstrate inexperience or lack of understanding of strategy
words.name: donk bet

words.def: a weak player, also known as fish or a donk
words.name: donkey

words.def: In a stud game, a player's first face-up card
words.name: door card

words.def: Under unconventional rules, a flush with one or more wild cards in which they play as aces, even if an ace is already present
words.name: double-ace flush

words.def: a combination of hole cards and exposed cards in hold 'em or stud games which does not include four connected cards, but where there are two different ranks of card that complete a straight
words.name: double belly buster straight draw

words.def: Any of several community card game variants (usually Texas hold 'em) in which two separate boards of community cards are dealt simultaneously, with the pot split between the winning hands using each board.
words.name: double-board, double-flop

words.def: Any of several draw poker games in which the draw phase and subsequent betting round are repeated twice
words.name: double-draw

words.def: The minimum raise in a no-limit or pot-limit game, raising by just the amount of the current bet.
words.name: double raise

words.def: An Omaha hold 'em starting hand where two pairs of suited cards are held
words.name: double suited

words.def: In a big bet game, to bet all of one's chips on one hand against a single opponent (who has an equal or larger stack) and win, thereby doubling the stack
words.name: double up, double through

words.def: A card that is dealt face-down
words.name: downcard

words.def: A period during which a player loses more than expected. See also: upswing.
words.name: downswing

words.def: To pull chips away from the pot to indicate that the player does not have enough money to cover a bet. If their hand wins, the amount is ignored. If not, they must cover the amount out of pocket. This is not allowed at any casino.
words.name: drag light

words.def: See main article: draw
words.name: draw, drawing hand, come hand

words.def: Playing a drawing hand that will lose even if successful
words.name: drawing dead

words.def: Not drawing dead; that is, drawing to a hand that will win if successful
words.name: drawing live

words.def: Not drawing completely dead, but chasing a draw in the face of poor odds
words.name: drawing thin

words.def: To fold
words.name: drop

words.def: In Omaha hold 'em or Texas hold 'em, an ace in one's hand without another card of the same suit. Used especially to denote the situation where the board presents a flush possibility, when the player does not in fact have a flush, but holding the ace presents some bluffing or semi-bluffing opportunity and a redraw in case the flush draw comes on the turn or the river. Compare with blocker.
words.name: dry ace

words.def: A measure of texture of the community cards. A board is considered dry when the cards on the table mean that is unlikely or impossible that any player has made a strong hand like a straight or flush. Compare with wet board.
words.name: dry board

words.def: A side pot with no money created when a player goes all in and is called by more than one opponent, but not raised. If subsequent betting occurs, the money will go to the dry pot.
words.name: dry pot

words.def: To counterfeit, especially when the counterfeiting card matches one already present in one's hand
words.name: duplicate

words.def: See position.
words.name: early position

words.def: A common qualifier in high-low split games that use ace-5 ranking. Only hands where the highest card is an eight or less can win the low portion of the pot.
words.name: eight or better

words.def: One's mathematical expected value from the current deal, calculated by multiplying the amount of money in the pot by one's probability of winning. If a split is possible, the equity also includes the probability of winning a split times the size of that split.
words.name: equity

words.def: See main article: expected value. Used in poker to mean profitability in the long run.
words.name: expectation, expected value, EV

words.def: A card whose face has been deliberately or accidentally revealed to players normally not entitled to that information during the play of the game. Various games have different rules about how to handle this irregularity. Compare with boxed card.
words.name: exposed card

words.def: A deal in which every (or almost every) seated player calls the first opening bet.
words.name: family pot

words.def: Aggressive play. Compare with speeding.
words.name: fast

words.def: A hand which, when matched against another in a showdown, has an advantage odds-wise over the other. A hand can be called a small or a big favorite depending on how much it is dominating the other. Contrast underdog where the situations are reversed. Favorites are usually used to compare how two hole cards do against two other hole cards pre-flop.
words.name: favorite

words.def: In a casino setting, a second or third table playing the same game as the main table, and from which players move to the main game as players are eliminated. Also called a must-move table.
words.name: feeder

words.def: The cloth covering of a poker table, whatever the actual material. Metonymically, the table itself.
words.name: felt

words.def: All players as a collective in a large tournament.
words.name: field

words.def: The last card dealt to the board in community card games. Also see river.
words.name: fifth street

words.def: To successfully draw to a hand that needs one card to complete it, by getting the last card of a straight, flush, or full house.
words.name: fill, fill up

words.def: The last table in a multi-table poker tournament. The final table is set when a sufficient number of people have been eliminated from the tournament leaving an exact amount of players to occupy one table (typically no more than ten players).
words.name: final table

words.def: The playing position to the direct left of the blinds in Texas hold 'em and Omaha hold 'em, also known as under the gun. The player in first position must act first on the first round of betting.
words.name: first position

words.def: A weak player. See also donkey.
words.name: fish

words.def: A hand possible only in games with wild cards, or a game with more than one deck, defeating all other hands, comprising five cards of equal rank.
words.name: five of a kind

words.def: See main article: fixed limits.
words.name: fixed limit, flat limit

words.def: Any card which becomes briefly exposed by accident to at least one player must be shown to all the players by the dealer during dealing. The card is said to be flashed to all players before being discarded to the muck pile. See also exposed.
words.name: flash

words.def: A call, in a situation where one might be expected to raise. Also smooth call. Compare with cold call, overcall. See slow play.
words.name: flat call

words.def: Calling a bet with the intention of bluffing on a later betting round.
words.name: float

words.def: A casino employee whose duties include adjudicating player disputes, keeping games filled and balanced, and managing dealers and other personnel. Players may shout "floor" to call for a floorperson to resolve a dispute, to ask for a table or seat change, or to ask for some other casino service.
words.name: floorman, floorperson

words.def: The dealing of the first three face-up cards to the board, refers also to those three cards themselves. Also see turn and river.
words.name: flop

words.def: A community card game.
words.name: flop game

words.def: A hand comprising five cards of the same suit. See List of poker hands.
words.name: flush

words.def: To discard one's hand and forfeit interest in the current pot. See main article: fold.
words.name: fold

words.def: The portion of the pot one expects to win, on average, by a bet that induces opponents to fold, rather than seeing the showdown. See also equity.
words.name: fold equity

words.def: See main article: forced bets.
words.name: forced bet

words.def: In a casino where more than one table is playing the same game with the same betting structure, one of the tables may be designated the main table, and will be kept full by requiring a player to move from one of the feeder tables to fill any vacancies. Players will generally be informed that their table is a forced-move table to be used in this way before they agree to play there. Also must-move.
words.name: forced-move

words.def: A house rule of some casinos states that if a player in turn picks up chips from their stack and moves their hand toward the pot (forward motion with chips in hand), this constitutes a commitment to bet (or call), and the player may not withdraw their hand to check or fold. Such a player still has the choice of whether to call or raise. Compare with string bet.
words.name: forward motion

words.def: A hand that is ruled unplayable because of an irregularity, such as being found with too many or too few cards, having been mixed with cards of other players or the muck, having fallen off the table. Compare with dead hand.
words.name: fouled hand

words.def: Four cards of the same suit. A non-standard poker hand in some games, an incomplete drawing hand in most. See main article: four flush.
words.name: four-flush

words.def: A hand containing four cards of equal rank. Also quads. See list of poker hands.
words.name: four of a kind

words.def: Four cards in rank sequence; either an open-ender or one-ender. A non-standard poker hand in some games, an incomplete drawing hand in most. Sometimes four to a straight.
words.name: four-straight

words.def: The fourth card dealt to the board in community card games. Also turn.
words.name: fourth street

words.def: A card dealt to one's hand (or to the board of community cards) after a betting round in which no player opened. One is thereby being given a chance to improve one's hand without having to pay anything.
words.name: free card

words.def: See main article: freeroll.
words.name: freeroll

words.def: The most common form of tournament. There are no rebuys and play continues until one player has all the chips.
words.name: freezeout

words.def: A hand with three cards of one rank and two of a second rank. Also boat or tight. See list of poker hands.
words.name: full house, full boat, full hand, full

words.def: In some casinos, the rule that a player must wager the full amount required in order for their action to constitute a raise. Compare with half bet rule. See public cardroom rules and all in betting.
words.name: full bet rule

words.def: A full ring game is a cash game with more than six players involved, typically nine to eleven. This term is normally used in the context of online poker. Compare with shorthanded.
words.name: full ring

words.def: In Texas hold 'em, a gap hand is a starting hand with at least one rank separating the two cards. Usually referred to in context of one-gap and two-gap hands.
words.name: gap hand

words.def: To fold a strong hand against a supposedly superior hand. Compare with laydown.
words.name: get away

words.def: To sneak a portion of chips from the table while the game is underway. Normally prohibited in public card rooms. Also ratholing.
words.name: going south

words.def: A player who earns a living by making small profits over a long period of consistent, conservative play. Compare with rock.
words.name: grinder

words.def: A game with no opening hand requirement.
words.name: guts, guts to open

words.def: See inside straight draw.
words.name: gut shot, gutshot

words.def: To enter the pot cheaply by just calling the blind rather than raising. Also limp.
words.name: gypsy

words.def: In some casinos, the rule that placing chips equal to or greater than half the normal bet amount beyond the amount required to call constitutes a commitment to raise the normal amount. Compare with full bet rule. See Public cardroom rules and "all in" betting
words.name: half bet rule

words.def: See main article: hand
words.name: hand

words.def: See main article: hand-for-hand
words.name: hand-for-hand

words.def: The textual representation of a hand (or hands) played in an Internet cardroom. See poker tools
words.name: hand history

words.def: When the bottom card of the deck sticks out beyond the others, an unwanted tell that the dealer is dealing from the bottom of the deck.
words.name: hanger

words.def: Playing against a single opponent
words.name: heads up poker

words.def: See rush
words.name: heater

words.def: Calling when a player has a relatively weak hand but suspects their opponent may be bluffing
words.name: hero call

words.def: The best hand using traditional poker hand values, as opposed to lowball. Used especially in high-low split games.
words.name: high hand, high

words.def: A no pair hand, ranked according to its highest-ranking cards
words.name: high card

words.def: See main article: high-low split
words.name: high-low, high-low split

words.def: The seat to the right of the cutoff seat, or second to the right of the button. This is generally considered to be the easiest position to steal the blinds from in tournaments, hence the name.
words.name: hijack seat

words.def: Face-down cards. Also pocket cards
words.name: hole cards, hole

words.def: A camera that displays a player's face-down cards (hole cards) to television viewers. Also pocket cam or lipstick cam
words.name: hole cam

words.def: A game played at a private venue (usually the home of one of the players), as opposed to a casino or public cardroom.
words.name: home game

words.def: A player financially backed by someone else. Compare with bankroll and staking
words.name: horse

words.def: See main article: H.O.R.S.E.
words.name: H.O.R.S.E.

words.def: In flop games, a player drawing to, or even flopping, a straight with undercards to the flop has the idiot end of it. A player with 8-9 betting on a flop of A-T-J puts themself at great risk, because many of the cards that complete their straight give credible opponents higher ones.
words.name: ignorant end, idiot end

words.def: See main article: implied pot odds
words.name: implied pot odds, implied odds

words.def: To achieve a better hand than one currently holds by adding or exchanging cards as provided in the rules of the game being played.
words.name: improve

words.def: See inside straight draw. Also "belly buster", "gutshot". Compare to outside straight draw
words.name: inside straight

words.def: A player is said to be in position, if the player is last to act on the flop, turn and river betting rounds. Compare with out of position
words.name: in position

words.def: A deal in which players agree to split or reduce a pot (roughly in proportion to the chances of each of them winning) with more cards to come rather than playing out the hand, or a deal where one player makes a side bet against themself with a third party to hedge against a large loss.
words.name: insurance

words.def: In a game with multiple blinds, an incoming player may sometimes be allowed to post the blinds in the middle (that is, out of their normal order) rather than having to wait for them to pass.
words.name: in the middle

words.def: To finish high enough in a poker tournament to win prize money
words.name: in the money

words.def: A player is said to be in turn if that player is expected to act next under the rules.
words.name: in turn

words.def: An action taken by a player in turn that is not a straightforward declaration of intent, but that is reasonably interpreted as an action by other players, such as pointing a thumb up to signify a raise. House rules or dealer discretion may determine when such actions are meaningful and binding.
words.name: irregular declaration

words.def: Any of a number of abnormal conditions in play, such as unexpectedly exposed cards, that may call for corrective action. See public cardroom rules
words.name: irregularity

words.def: See main article: isolation
words.name: isolation

words.def: A game of jackpot poker or jackpots, which is a variant of five-card draw with an ante from each player, no blinds, and an opening requirement of a pair of jacks or better.
words.name: jackpot

words.def: A 53rd card used mostly in draw games. The joker may usually be used as an ace, or a card to complete a straight or flush, in high games, and as the lowest card not already present in a hand at low. See bug
words.name: joker

words.def: Money collected by the house. Also vig, vigorish. See rake
words.name: juice

words.def: A hand with little expected value
words.name: junk

words.def: See main article: kicker
words.name: kicker

words.def: In a kill game, a button that shows which player has the kill action. See main article: kill game
words.name: kill button

words.def: See main article: kill game
words.name: kill game, kill pot

words.def: A hand with different betting rules in a kill game. See main article: kill game
words.name: kill hand

words.def: A pool of money built by collecting small amounts from certain pots, often used to buy refreshments, cards, and so on. The home-game equivalent of a rake.
words.name: kitty

words.def: A loose aggressive style of play in which a player plays a lot of starting hands and makes many small raises in hopes of out-playing their opponents
words.name: lag

words.def: A player is last to act if all players between the player and the button have folded.
words.name: last to act

words.def: The choice to fold a strong hand in anticipation of superior opposition
words.name: laydown

words.def: The player who makes the last bet or raise in a round of betting is said to have the lead at the start of the next round. Can also be used as a verb meaning to bet out into the pot, to lead into the pot.
words.name: lead

words.def: Used in tournament play to refer to the size of the blinds that are periodically increased
words.name: level

words.def: The button used to signify who has won the previous hand in a kill game
words.name: leg-up, leg-up button

words.def: A hand that is not likely to be best. Usually used as an action descriptor; call light, three-bet light. See semi-bluff
words.name: light

words.def: The minimum or maximum amount of a bet
words.name: limit

words.def: To enter a pot by simply calling a bet instead of raising
words.name: limp, limp in

words.def: A reraise from a player that previously limped in the same betting round. Also backraise
words.name: limp-reraise

words.def: A bet posted by a player under conditions that give them the option to raise even if no other player raises first; typically because it was posted as a blind or straddle.
words.name: live bet.

words.def: In stud poker games, cards that will improve a hand that have not been seen among anyone's upcards, and are therefore presumably still available. In games such as Texas hold 'em, a player's hand is said to contain live cards if matching either of them on the board would give that player the lead over their opponents. Typically refers to a hand that is weak, but not dominated.
words.name: live cards

words.def: A hand still eligible to win the pot; one with the correct number of cards that has not been mucked or otherwise invalidated
words.name: live hand

words.def: A game with a lot of action. See also live poker.
words.name: live game

words.def: A retronym for poker played at a table with cards, as opposed to video poker or online poker
words.name: live poker

words.def: To lock up a seat in a cash game means to place a poker chip, player's card, or other personal effect on the table in front of the seat, to signify that the seat is occupied even though the player may not be present.
words.name: lock up

words.def: To play more hands than the average for the game or for the player normally. See loose/tight play. Compare with tight, aggressive, passive.
words.name: loose

words.def: The lowest card by rank
words.name: low

words.def: A measure of the health of a chip stack as a function of the cost to play each round. See main article: M-ratio.
words.name: M-ratio

words.def: A hand that does not need improvement to win. Compare with a drawing hand.
words.name: made hand

words.def: A very loose and aggressive player, who bets and raises frequently, and often in situations where it is not good strategy to do so. Opposite of rock.
words.name: maniac

words.def: A person at a poker table that is the focus of attention, often due to their inexperience
words.name: mark

words.def: To bet an amount equal to all the chips in the pot
words.name: match the pot

words.def: Internet poker games with stakes so small that real cardrooms could not profit from them, are said to be at the micro-limit level.
words.name: micro-limit

words.def: In a community card game, making a pair with neither the highest nor lowest card of the community cards. See also second pair.
words.name: middle pair

words.def: See position
words.name: middle position

words.def: A deal which is ruined for some reason and must be redealt
words.name: misdeal

words.def: A required bet that is not posted when it is a player's turn to do so, perhaps occurring when a player absents themself from the table. Various rules require the missed bet to be made up upon the player's return.
words.name: missed blind

words.def: In a no-limit game, to move in or to go all in means to bet one's entire stake on the hand in play. See table stakes.
words.name: move in

words.def: See Poker tournament
words.name: multi-table tournament (MTT)

words.def: To fold
words.name: muck

words.def: A pot where several players compete for it. Also known as a family pot, although family pot sometimes means a pot where all players participate.
words.name: multi-way pot

words.def: See main article: negative freeroll.
words.name: negative freeroll

words.def: A player who is unwilling to take risks and plays only premium hands in the top range.
words.name: nit

words.def: Rules designating that players are allowed to wager any or all of their chips in a single bet. See no-limit
words.name: no-limit

words.def: When a player only has the possibility of a high card and no other hand that will win.
words.name: nothing

words.def: The nut hand is the best possible hand in a given situation. Players sometimes evaluate hands by ranking them as being the second nuts or the pure nuts.
words.name: nut hand (the nuts)

words.def: The best possible low hand in high-low split games
words.name: nut low

words.def: Cards that are not of the same suit
words.name: offsuit

words.def: A call of a previous bet using a chip of a higher denomination than necessary is considered a call unless it is verbally announced as a raise.
words.name: one-chip rule

words.def: See main article: one-eyed royals
words.name: one-eyed royals

words.def: Four out of the five cards needed for a straight that can only be completed with one specific rank of card, in cases where the needed card rank is either higher or lower than the cards already held as part of the sequence; as opposed to an inside straight draw or an open-ended straight draw.
words.name: one-ended straight draw

words.def: To bet first. See main article: open
words.name: open

words.def: An outside straight draw. Also two-way straight draw or double-ended straight draw
words.name: open-ended straight draw, open-ended

words.def: The cards held by a player in a game of jackpots entitling them to open the pot. Splitting openers refers to holding onto one of the openers after discarding it as proof of having the necessary cards to open.
words.name: openers

words.def: Being the first person in the pot preflop, but not raising
words.name: open limp

words.def: An optional bet or draw
words.name: option

words.def: A full rotation of the blinds at a table, equal to the number of people at the table.
words.name: orbit

words.def: See main article: out
words.name: outs

words.def: A player is said to be out of position, if they are either first to act, or are not last to act in a betting round.
words.name: out of position,

words.def: See main article: outside straight draw. Also two-way straight draw or double-ended straight draw
words.name: outside straight draw

words.def: To make a bet that is more than the size of the pot in a no limit game
words.name: overbet

words.def: To call a bet after others have called. Compare with cold call, flat call, smooth call
words.name: overcall

words.def: A community card with a higher rank than a player's pocket pair
words.name: overcard

words.def: In community card games such as Texas hold 'em and Omaha hold 'em, a pocket pair with a higher rank than the highest community card.
words.name: overpair

words.def: An option to increase the stakes in limit games. Players may elect to play or not play overs. Those who choose to play display some sort of token. If, at the beginning of a betting round, only overs players remain in the hand, bets of a predetermined increased limit (or no limit) are allowed. Most often used in lower limit live games as a compromise between aggressive and passive play.
words.name: overs

words.def: Any royal card. Used mostly in lowball games, where royal cards are rarely helpful.
words.name: paint

words.def: Two cards of the same rank. See main article: one pair
words.name: pair

words.def: A style of play characterized by checking and calling. Compare with aggressive, loose, tight
words.name: passive

words.def: Already complete. A hand is a pat hand when, for example, a flush comes on the first five cards dealt in draw poker. Also see made hand
words.name: pat

words.def: To call a bet when the player is most likely drawing dead because the pot odds justify the call.
words.name: pay off

words.def: Frivolous, low stakes, or for fun only; a game where no significant stake is likely to change hands.
words.name: penny ante

words.def: The best possible cards, in a lowball hand, after those already named.
words.name: perfect

words.def: When the house picks up cash from the dealer after a player buys chips
words.name: pick-up

words.def: In games such as Texas hold 'em, where five community cards are dealt, if the player's best hand is on the board and the player goes to the showdown they are said to play the board.
words.name: play the board

words.def: See hole cards
words.name: pocket cards

words.def: In community card poker or stud poker, when two of a player's private cards make a pair. Also wired pair
words.name: pocket pair

words.def: A blank expression that does not reveal anything about the cards being held.
words.name: poker face

words.def: See main article: position
words.name: position

words.def: A bet that is made more due to the strength of the bettor's position than the strength of the bettor's cards.
words.name: position bet

words.def: To make the required small or big blind bet in Texas hold 'em or other games played with blinds rather than antes.
words.name: post

words.def: To post a bet amount equal to the small and the big blind combined (the amount of the large blind playing as a live blind, and the amount of the small blind as dead money). In games played with blinds, a player who steps away from the table and misses their turn for the blinds must either post dead or wait for the big blind to re-enter the game. Compare with dead blind
words.name: post dead

words.def: See main article: post oak bluff
words.name: post oak bluff

words.def: See main article: pot
words.name: pot

words.def: More often in the context of a no limit game; the situation where one can no longer fold because the size of the pot is so large compared to the size of one's stack.
words.name: pot-committed

words.def: See main article: pot limit
words.name: pot-limit

words.def: See main article: pot odds
words.name: pot odds

words.def: The time when players already have their pocket cards but no flop has been dealt yet.
words.name: pre-flop

words.def: A bet after the flop by a player who did not take the lead in betting before the flop (and when the player that did take the lead in betting before the flop declined to act). Compare with continuation bet
words.name: probe bet

words.def: A player who gets paid an hourly rate to start poker games or to help them stay active. Prop players play with their own money, which distinguishes them from shills, who play with the house's money.
words.name: prop, proposition player

words.def: A pot that seems impossible to bluff to win because too many players are active in it and the chances of another player either calling to the end or raising beyond measure become an assurance.
words.name: protected pot

words.def: See main article: protection
words.name: protection, protect

words.def: The total prize pool in a poker tournament
words.name: purse

words.def: To bet all in
words.name: push

words.def: See main article: call the clock
words.name: put the clock (on someone)

words.def: To put someone on a hand is to deduce what hand or range of hands they have based on their actions and knowledge of their gameplay style. See also tells
words.name: put on

words.def: Four of a kind
words.name: quads

words.def: A qualifying low hand. High-low split games often require a minimum hand value, such as eight-high, in order to award the low half of the pot. In some home games, there are qualifiers for high hands as well.
words.name: qualifier, qualifying low

words.def: To win a quarter of a pot, usually by tying the low or high hand of a high-low split game. Generally, this is an unwanted outcome, as a player is often putting in a third of the pot in the hope of winning a quarter of the pot back.
words.name: quartered

words.def: After a hand is complete, to reveal cards that would have been dealt later in the hand had it continued. This is usually prohibited in casinos because it slows the game and may reveal information about concealed hands. Also fox hunt
words.name: rabbit hunt

words.def: A poor player. See also fish
words.name: raccoon

words.def: A collection of 100 chips of the same denomination, usually arranged in five stacks in a plastic tray.
words.name: rack

words.def: See coin flip
words.name: race

words.def: A low-valued (and presumably worthless) card. Hence ragged - having a low value
words.name: rag

words.def: The rail is the sideline at a poker table—the (often imaginary) rail separates spectators from the field of play. Watching from the rail means watching a poker game as a spectator. Going to the rail usually means losing all one's money.
words.name: rail

words.def: A non-participatory spectator of a poker game
words.name: railbird

words.def: Three or four cards of different suits, especially said of a flop.
words.name: rainbow

words.def: See main article: raise
words.name: raise

words.def: See main article: rake. Also juice, vig, vigorish
words.name: rake

words.def: Rebate or repayment to a player a portion of the rake paid by that player, normally from a non-cardroom, third-party source such as an affiliate. Rakeback is paid in many ways by online poker rooms, affiliates or brick and mortar rooms. Many use direct money payments for online poker play. Brick and mortar rooms usually use rate cards to track and pay their rakeback. See main article: rakeback
words.name: rakeback

words.def: A rakeback pro is a poker player who may not be a winning player but uses rakebacks to supplement their losses and turn them into winnings.
words.name: rakeback pro

words.def: The list of holdings that a player considers an opponent might have when trying to deduce their holding. See also put on
words.name: range of hands

words.def: To remove a portion of one's chips from the table while the game is underway. Normally prohibited in public card rooms. Also going south
words.name: rathole

words.def: An amount of chips purchased after the buy-in. In some tournaments, players are allowed to rebuy chips one or more times for a limited period after the start of the game, providing that their stack is at or under its initial level. Compare with add-on
words.name: rebuy

words.def: To deal a hand again, possibly after a misdeal
words.name: redeal

words.def: To make one hand and have a draw for a better hand
words.name: redraw

words.def: To represent a hand is to play as if it were held (whether it is or not).
words.name: represent

words.def: Raise after one has been raised. Also coming over the top
words.name: reraise

words.def: See main article: ring game
words.name: ring game

words.def: The river or river card is the final card dealt in a poker hand, to be followed by a final round of betting and, if necessary, a showdown. In Texas hold 'em and Omaha hold'em, the river is the fifth and last card to be dealt to the community card board, after the flop and turn. A player losing the pot due only to the river card is said to have been rivered.
words.name: river

words.def: A very tight player (plays very few hands and only continues with strong hands).
words.name: rock

words.def: In seven-card stud, three of a kind dealt in the first three cards
words.name: rolled-up trips

words.def: An expert player who travels to seek out high-stakes games
words.name: rounder

words.def: Royal card are also known as face cards and picture cards. These cards consist of the jack, queen, and king of every suit.
words.name: royal cards

words.def: A straight flush of the top five cards of any suit. This is generally the highest possible hand.
words.name: royal flush

words.def: A gentleman's agreement (not allowed in some casinos) where the players (usually two or three) agree to draw each remaining card to come in two different occasions instead of just once after all parties have gone all-in (two flops, turns and river for example for a total of 10 community cards in two sets of five). The winner of one run gets half the pot while the winner of the second run gets the other half. Running it twice is done to minimize bad beats and reduce bankroll swings. Running it twice is a form of insurance.
words.name: run it twice, running it twice

words.def: A hand made by hitting two consecutive cards on the turn and river. Also backdoor. Compare with bad beat and suck out
words.name: runner-runner

words.def: A prolonged winning streak. A player who has won several big pots recently is said to be on a rush. Also heater
words.name: rush

words.def: See slow play (poker)
words.name: sandbag

words.def: A tournament in which the prize is a free entrance to another (larger) tournament.
words.name: satellite

words.def: A card dealt face up (either to a player in a game such as stud or to the board in a community card game) that could create a strong hand for someone.
words.name: scare card

words.def: In high-low split games, to win both the high and the low halves of the pot.
words.name: scoop

words.def: In community card poker games, a pair of cards of the second-top rank on the board. Second pair is a middle pair, but not necessarily vice versa. Compare with bottom pair, top pair
words.name: second pair

words.def: In spread limit poker, to sell a hand is to bet less than the maximum with a strong hand, in the hope that more opponents will call the bet.
words.name: sell

words.def: When a player bluffs on one round of betting with an inferior or drawing hand that might improve in a later round. See main article: semi-bluff
words.name: semi-bluff

words.def: Three of a kind, especially a situation where two of the cards are concealed in the player's hole cards. Compare with trips
words.name: set

words.def: A deck that has been ordered, usually king to ace by suit (spades, hearts, clubs and diamonds). In casinos, it is customary to use a set-up deck when introducing a new deck to the table. The set-up is spread face up for the players to demonstrate that all of the cards are present before the first shuffle. Also called spading the deck
words.name: set-up

words.def: A rule in many A-5 lowball games that requires a player with a seven-low or better after the draw to bet, rather than check or check-raise. In some venues, a violator loses any future interest in the pot; in others they forfeit their interest entirely.
words.name: sevens rule

words.def: A professional player. See also card sharp
words.name: shark

words.def: See main article: shill. Compare with proposition player
words.name: shill

words.def: A slanted container used to hold the cards yet to be dealt, usually used by casinos and in professional poker tournaments. See main article: shoe (cards).
words.name: shoe

words.def: A poker tournament format where the last remaining player of a table goes on to play the remaining players of other tables. Each table plays independently of the others; that is, there is no balancing as players are eliminated.
words.name: shootout

words.def: In no-limit poker, to buy into a game for considerably less money than the stated maximum buyin, or less than other players at the table have in play.
words.name: short buy

words.def: A stack of chips that is relatively small for the stakes being played. Compare with deep stack, big stack
words.name: short stack

words.def: A poker game that is played with six players or fewer, as opposed to a full ring game, which is usually nine or ten players. A tournament where all tables are shorthanded at all times is called a short table tournament.
words.name: shorthanded

words.def: When, if more than one player remains after the last betting round, remaining players expose and compare their hands to determine the winner or winners. See main article: showdown
words.name: showdown

words.def: A ring game running concurrently with a tournament made up of players who have either been eliminated or opted not to play the tournament.
words.name: side game

words.def: A separate pot created to deal with the situation of one player going "all in". See Betting in poker
words.name: side pot

words.def: A poker tournament with no scheduled starting time that starts whenever the necessary players have put up their money. Single-table sit-and-gos, with nine or ten players, are the norm, but multi-table games are common as well. Also called sit 'n gos
words.name: sit and go

words.def: See main article: slow play
words.name: slow play

words.def: To delay or avoid showing the winning hand at showdown, it is widely regarded as poor etiquette.
words.name: slow roll

words.def: See main article: blinds
words.name: small blind

words.def: When someone manages to catch a slightly better hand.
words.name: smooched

words.def: See flat call
words.name: smooth call

words.def: When a player makes a swift call without any forethought (usually against an all-in) because of the high strength of their hand.
words.name: snap call

words.def: To play a worthless hand misleadingly in draw poker in order to bluff.
words.name: snow

words.def: To intentionally go easy on a player. Soft play is expressly prohibited in most card rooms, and may result in penalties ranging from forced sit-outs to forfeiture of stakes or winnings.
words.name: soft-play

words.def: Exchanging a large bill or chip into both chips and cash, when a player buys in. The cash is returned to the player and thus not in play.
words.name: soft break

words.def: To throw one's chips in the pot in a disorderly fashion. Not typically allowed, because the dealer can not tell how much has been bet.
words.name: splash the pot

words.def: See main article: split and high-low split
words.name: split

words.def: In community card poker, a two pair hand, with each pair made of one of a player's hole cards, and one community card.
words.name: split two pair

words.def: The range between a table's minimum and maximum bets
words.name: spread

words.def: A form of limit poker where the bets and raises can be between a minimum and maximum value. The spread may change between rounds.
words.name: spread-limit

words.def: A bluff reraise in no limit hold'em with less-than-premium cards, after another player or players have already called the original raise. The goal is to bluff everyone out of the hand and steal the bets.
words.name: squeeze play

words.def: The total chips and currency that a player has in play at a given moment
words.name: stack

words.def: The amount one buys in for and can bet.
words.name: stakes

words.def: Staking is the act of one person putting up cash for a poker player to play with in hopes that the player wins. Any profits are split on a predetermined percentage between the backer and the player. A backed player is often known as a horse. Compare with bankroll
words.name: staking

words.def: In draw poker, playing the original hand using no draws, either as a bluff or in the belief it is the best hand.
words.name: stand pat

words.def: See main article: starting hand
words.name: starting hand

words.def: See main article: steal
words.name: steal

words.def: A state of anger, mental confusion, or frustration in which a player adopts a less than optimal strategy, usually resulting in poor play. Compare with tilt
words.name: steam

words.def: When a player bets into another player who has previously raised or otherwise shown aggression.
words.name: stop and go

words.def: See main article: straddle bets
words.name: straddle bet

words.def: Poker hand: see main article: straight
words.name: straight

words.def: See main article: straight flush
words.name: straight flush

words.def: A wallet sized card that is commonly used to help with poker strategies in online and casino games.
words.name: strategy card

words.def: A street is another term for a dealt card or betting round.
words.name: street

words.def: A call with one motion and a later raise with another, or a reach for more chips without stating the intended amount. String bets are prohibited in public cardroom rules. Compare with forward motion
words.name: string bet

words.def: A structured betting system is one where the spread of the bets may change from round to round.
words.name: structured

words.def: A variant of poker. See main article: stud poker
words.name: stud

words.def: Subscription poker is a form of online poker wherein users pay a monthly fee to become eligible to play in real-money tournaments.
words.name: subscription poker

words.def: A situation when a hand heavily favored to win loses to an inferior hand after all the cards are dealt. The winning hand is said to have sucked out. Compare with bad beat
words.name: suck out

words.def: Having the same suit. See card suits
words.name: suited

words.def: See main article: suited connectors
words.name: suited connectors

words.def: A multi-table poker tournament in which the prize is a free entrance to a satellite tournament or a tournament in which all the top finishers gain entrance to a larger tournament.
words.name: super satellite

words.def: See main article: table stakes.
words.name: table stakes

words.def: A tight aggressive style of play in which a player plays a small number of strong starting hands, but when in pots plays aggressively.
words.name: tag

words.def: Cards that improve a hand so that it is better than the other current hands, but simultaneously improve other hands even more. See also outs
words.name: tainted outs

words.def: To take an excessive amount of time to act.
words.name: tank, in the tank

words.def: A tell in poker is a detectable change in a player's behavior or demeanor that gives clues to that player's assessment of their hand. See main article: tell
words.name: tell

words.def: How well coordinated the community cards are to one another. This is used to estimate relative hand strength. See also dry board and wet board
words.name: texture

words.def: A player who gets up from their seat in a cash game, after two other players are already away from the table, is referred to as the third man walking. In a casino with a third man walking rule, this player may be required to return to their seat within 10 minutes, or one rotation of the deal around the table, or else their seat in the game will be forfeited if there is a waiting list for the game.
words.name: third man walking

words.def: To be the first player to put in a third unit of betting.
words.name: three bet, three betting

words.def: See main article: three of a kind. Also trips, set
words.name: three of a kind

words.def: To play fewer hands than average for the game or for the player normally. See loose/tight play. Compare with loose, aggressive, passive
words.name: tight

words.def: Emotional upset, mental confusion, or frustration in which a player adopts a less than optimal strategy, usually resulting in poor play. See main article: tilt. Compare with steam
words.name: tilt

words.def: The amount that a player is required to call in order to stay in the hand.
words.name: to go

words.def: In a brick and mortar casino, a toke is a tip given to the dealer by the winner of the pot.
words.name: toke

words.def: In community card poker games, top kicker is the best possible kicker to some given hand.
words.name: top kicker

words.def: In community card poker games, top pair is a pair comprising a pocket card and the highest-ranking card on the board. Compare with second pair, bottom pair
words.name: top pair

words.def: A split two pair, matching the highest-ranking two flop cards.
words.name: top two

words.def: See slow play
words.name: trap

words.def: A three-spot card.
words.name: trey

words.def: A type of tournament where the blind levels increase much faster than in standard play.
words.name: turbo

words.def: The turn, turn card or fourth street is the fourth of five cards dealt to a community card board, constituting one face-up community card that each of the players in the game can use to make up their final hand. See also flop and river
words.name: turn

words.def: The playing position to the direct left of the blinds in Texas hold 'em or Omaha hold 'em. The player who is under the gun must act first on the first round of betting.
words.name: under the gun

words.def: An underdog or dog is a player with a smaller chance to win than another specified player. Frequently used when the exact odds are expressed.
words.name: underdog

words.def: A full house made where the three of a kind has lower-ranking cards than the pair. Compare with big full
words.name: underfull

words.def: When used with a card rank to describe a poker hand, refers to two pair with the named card being the higher pair.
words.name: up

words.def: A card that is played face up. See main article: upcard
words.name: upcard

words.def: A period during which a player wins more (or loses less) than expected. See also: downswing
words.name: upswing

words.def: Increase the stakes
words.name: up the ante

words.def: See raise
words.name: upstairs

words.def: A bet made by a player who wants it to be called (as opposed to a bluff or protection bet). See value
words.name: value bet

words.def: The statistical measure of how far actual results differ from expectation. See main article: variance
words.name: variance

words.def: The rake. See main article: vigorish
words.name: vigorish, vig

words.def: Voluntary put money in pot. Represents the percentage of hands with which a player puts money into the pot pre-flop, without counting any blind postings. VPIP is an excellent measure of how tight or loose a player is.
words.name: VPIP

words.def: To "wake up with a hand" means to discover a strong starting hand, often when there has already been action in front of the player.
words.name: wake up

words.def: A walk is a situation where all players fold to the big blind.
words.name: walk

words.def: To mix the deck by spreading the cards face down on the table and mixing them up.
words.name: wash

words.def: An ace with a low kicker. Also small ace, soft ace, ace-rag
words.name: weak ace

words.def: A player who is easily bullied out of a hand post-flop by any sort of action.
words.name: weak player

words.def: A form of online poker which allows players to watch each other during play via a webcam.
words.name: webcam poker

words.def: A wet board is when the cards on the table make it possible for players to have hit strong hands. Compare with dry board
words.name: wet board

words.def: A five-high straight (A-2-3-4-5), with the ace playing low. See list of poker hands and lowball (poker)
words.name: wheel

words.def: See main article: wild card. Compare with bug
words.name: wild card

words.def: An upcard in stud poker. The first window card in stud is called the door card. In Texas hold'em and Omaha, the window card is the first card shown when the dealer puts out the three cards for the flop.
words.name: window card

words.def: In Omaha hold 'em, a wrap is a straight draw with nine or more outs[5] comprising two board cards and three or four cards from a player's hand.
words.name: wrap
